A study on the fabrication of porous PVDF membranes by in-situ elimination and their applications in separating oil/water mixtures and nano-emulsions
Liwei Chen a,b, Yifan Si a,b, Hai Zhu a,b, Ting Jiang a,b, Zhiguang Guo a,b,n
a Hubei Collaborative Innovation Centre for Advanced Organic Chemical Materials and Ministry of Education Key Laboratory for the Green Preparation and Application of Functional Materials, Hubei University, Wuhan 430062, China b State Key Laboratory of Solid Lubrication, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Lanzhou 730000, China

Keywords: PVDF Porous membrane Oil/water separation Emulsion separation In-situ elimination

a b s t r a c t
The influences and treatments of oil/water mixtures have been plaguing people for many years. To deal with it, the fabrication of separation membranes becomes a significant technology in the application to oily wastewater treatment. Except for the well-known phase inversion method which is promising for polymeric separation membrane fabrication, another imaginable method referred to as in-situ elimination here still suffers from major difficulty in the uniform dispersion of dissoluble micro/nano-particles in polymeric matrix. Aiming at in-situ elimination method, a series of free-standing thin PVDF membranes with interconnected porous structures are fabricated based on low-cost starting materials through a simple process of tape-casting, drying and immersing, in the presence of pore-forming agent of citric acid monohydrate (CAM). Substantially, the pore formation mechanism is studied, which is resulted from the recrystallization of pore-forming agent (CAM) and subsequent in-situ elimination in NaHCO3 solution. The fabricated free-standing porous PVDF membrane with thickness of 5 mm and surface pore size of o500 nm showed great flexibility and superoleophilic, under-oil superhydrophobic, anti-water-fouling properties. For the porosity and selective wettability, their applications in oil/water separation are studied also and the results show that the PVDF membrane can separate not only immiscible oil/water mixtures quickly but also various surfactant-stabilized water-in-oil nanoscale emulsions, with filtration flux up to 318 L m 2 h 1 and separation efficiency of 99.81% under the action of self-gravity. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time the polymeric separation membranes have been positively fabricated by in-situ elimination, which provides a new avenue for porous polymeric membrane fabrication in membrane science field and shows the application in oil/water or emulsion separation. This work provides a new porous membrane-forming method and an energy-efficient strategy for separating immiscible oil/water mixtures and surfactant-stabilized water-in-oil nanoemulsions.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The problems of resource waste and ecosystem damages caused by oil spill and discharged oil/water mixtures have been plaguing people for a long time [1,2]. Because of the complex configurations, conventional separation skills are limited to immiscible oil/water mixtures but are ineffective for oil/water
ovation Centre for Advanced Key Laboratory for the Green s, Hubei University, Wuhan
emulsions, especially for surfactant-stabilized nano-emulsions [3– 6]. With the deep study of super-wetting phenomenon, series of selective permeation materials are developed based on metal meshes or foams [7–12], organic sponges [13–15], one/two-dimensional carbon films [16–20] and polymeric porous membranes [21–23]. However, most of them are shown to be complex, highcost, small-scale, weak mechanical strength, or/and low efficiency, which cannot meet the demand of practical applications [24–29]. Compared to easier controlling in pore size, the thickness of the separation materials is a self-limiting factor that the thinness of separation materials will be at the expense of mechanical strength. Hence, fabricating pore-controllable, thin, robust and selectivewetting separation materials remain a challenge. Recently, one/

two-dimensional carbon materials like carbon nanotube (CNT) and graphene oxide (GO) aroused much attention [16–20], since an ultrathin free-standing single-walled carbon nanotube (SWCNT) network film was fabricated to separate water-in-oil emulsions [16]. By adjusting the surface wettability with hydrophilic polyethyleneimine, polydopamine or UV-responsive TiO2, the SWCNT network film could be used to separate oil-in-water emulsions also [17–19]. These carbon-based materials are promising but high-cost and not suit for large-scale fabrication in practice.
As important and common base materials, polymers are preferable alternatives to fabricate separation membranes for their multifunctional groups and excellent performances in structural strength and manufacturability [30]. Among them, most of polymer materials (such as, PSF, PEG, PEI and so on) are less hydrophobic, thereby surface modification on polymeric membrane for oil/water separation is necessitated in some cases [31,32]. However, there is another kind of materials which are inherently hydrophobic. Polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) as fluoropolymer is typical one that shows superior chemical stability, flexibility and hydrophobicity [33–35]. For porous membrane, the most wellknown preparation method is phase inversion [36]. For instance, by an induced phase-inversion process, Zhang et al. prepared porous PVDF and PAA-g-PVDF membranes which could effectively separate emulsified oil/water mixtures [37,38]. Compared to phase-inversion method which involves complex physical-chemical processes, another method referred to as in-situ elimination here is possible. Conceiving that if micro/nano-particles can be dispersed into thin polymer matrix and then be resolved by the corresponding reactant, resulting in interconnected micro/nanoholes in situ, a thin porous polymeric membrane will be achieved. Compared with conventional phase inverse method, this new method is applicable various polymeric materials and shows flexibility in choosing the pairs of pore-forming agent and reactant. But it still suffers from major difficulty in the uniform dispersion of micro/nano-particles (i.e., pore-forming agent) in polymeric matrix.
In this work, we reported a new and simple method of in-situ elimination for porous polymeric membranes fabrication and studied the mechanism of pore formation in the presence of poreforming agent CAM (citric acid monohydrate). This method is easier to control the membrane thickness under 10 mm via tapecasting and the pore size at nanoscale via recrystallization. The fabricated membranes were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) and water/oil contact angle (W/OCA). The effects of CAM content on the surface morphology, porosity, wettability and oil permeation rate were investigated. Finally, the performances of the porous PVDF membrane in separating both immiscible and emulsified oil/water mixtures were further studied by dynamic light scattering (DLS) and coulometric KF (Karl Fischer) titrator.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Poly(vinylidene fluoride) powder (PVDF, CAS: 24937-79-9, Density: 1.74 g/mL at 25 °C, average Mw: 534,000) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. N-dimethyl formamide (DMF, Z99.5%) was purchased from Rionlon Bohua (Tianjin, China) Pharmaceutical & Chemical Co. Ltd. Citric acid monohydrate (CAM, 99.8%) and sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3, Z99.5%) were purchased from Xilong (China) Chemical Co. Ltd. All other chemicals were analytical-grade reagents and used as received.

sections.heading: 2.2. Fabrication of free-standing, thin, porous PVDF membranes
sections.text:
The free-standing, thin, porous PVDF membranes were fabricated through a special procedure of tape-casting, drying, immersing and skimming, which is schematically shown in Fig. 1. Firstly, a CAM/PVDF/DMF polymeric precursor solution was prepared by dissolving certain amount (0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0 mmol) of citric acid monohydrate (CAM) and 0.6 g of PVDF powder in 10 mL of the solvent N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF). The recipe of the mixed solution is listed in Table 1. Next, to obtain thin membranes, the tape-casting method is applied here (Fig. 1a). 2 mL of the polymeric mixed solution was sucked up with a plastic straw and coated onto a pre-cleaned glass plate (8 8 cm) via tape-casting method and then obliquely place it into a drying oven at 60 °C for 30 min. When the coated glass plate is tilted, the excess polymeric solution will flow down, leaving a thin coating layer on the surface of tilted glass plate. At the same time, predissolved CAM recrystallizes into micro/nano-particles that are uniformly dispersed and embedded in the cured PVDF membrane. As a result, a thin membrane with CAM crystals was formed on the glass substrate (Fig. 1b). Finally, to obtain free-standing and porous membrane, a strategy of immersing and in-situ elimination is applied. The cured polymeric membrane on glass plate was immersed in the concentrated NaHCO3 aqueous solution (10 M aq.) for 30 min. Due to polymer swelling, the membrane is easily released from the smooth rigid glass surface, accompanying obvious
release of CO2 bubbles (Fig. 1c). The released membrane floats on the liquid surface for its hydrophobicity. With a stainless steel ring, the floating membrane was lifted up and then dried at 60 °C for 10 min after adequate rinsing by ethyl alcohol and deionized water, successively (Fig. 1d). After drying, the hooped membrane can be taken down carefully and cut into desired size. With such a simple procedure, a series of free-standing, thin, porous PVDF membranes with the area of 8 8 cm are fabricated at low cost. According to the amount of CAM added from 0 to 1.0 mmol, the fabricated membranes were respectively referred to as M1, M2, M3, M4, M5 and M6 (Table 1).

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of various surfactant-stabilized water-in-oil nanoscale emulsions
sections.text: For the surfactant-stabilized water-in-cyclohexane emulsion (SSE-1): 0.02 g of span80 was added into 100 mL of cyclohexane and then 1 mL of DI water was added also. The mixture was vigorously stirred for 6 h. For the surfactant-stabilized water-in-isooctane emulsion (SSE-2): a mixture of 100 mL of isooctane, 1 mL of DI water and 0.04 g of span 80 was stirred for 6 h. For the surfactant-stabilized water-in-hexane emulsion (SSE-3): 100 mL of isooctane, 1 mL of DI water and 0.04 g of span 80 were mixed and continuously stirred for 6 h. For the surfactant-stabilized water-inchloroform (SSE-4) emulsion: 100 mL of chloroform and 1 mL of DI water were stirred for 6 h in the presence of 0.04 g of span 80. The acronyms, compositions and proportions of various emulsions are summarized in Table 2. The droplet sizes and distribution were measured by dynamic light scattering (DLS) measurements. From Table 2, one can clearly see that the sizes of these surfactant-stabilized emulsions are nanoscale, which are ranged from 100– 800 nm. All the surfactant-stabilized water-in-oil emulsions were stable during the whole experiment and no de-emulsification or precipitation was observed. In the experiments of emulsion separation, each testing was repeated for three times.

sections.heading: 2.4. Characterization
sections.text:
The cross-section and surface structures of the membranes were performed on a field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, JEOL JSM-6701F) both with Au-sputtered specimens. The surface compositions of the membranes were analyzed on X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi), fourier transformer infrared spectra (FTIR, Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS10) and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) attached to the scanning electron microscopes (SEM, JEOL JSM5600LV). The transparency of the membranes was detected by UV– Vis Spectrum (Cary 60 UV–Vis, Agilent Technologies). The water and oil contact angles (WCA and OCA) and water adhesion of the membranes in air and/or under oil were measured at ambient temperature on a JC20001 contact angle system (Zhongchen
digital equipment Co., Ltd. Shanghai, China), using a 5 μL deionized water droplet and a 3 μL 1, 2-dichloroethane droplet. Because of the porosity and thinness of the membranes, the measurements were carried out on the membranes which were suspended by two glass slides to avoid the influence of substrate. The size and size distribution of emulsions were measured by dynamic light scattering (DLS) performed on a Zetasizer Nano ZS (Malvern 3600, UK) and optical microscope using OLYMPUS BX51 microscope. Water contents in the filtrates were measured by using a coulometric Karl Fischer titrator (Metrohm KFC20, Switzerland). All photographs were taken using a digital camera (Sony DSCHX200).

sections.heading: 3.1. The effects of CAM content on membrane porosity and mechanical property
sections.text:
To know the effects of CAM content on membrane features, the main mechanism is embodied in following two aspects: recrystallization and in-situ elimination are utilized in the presence of pore-forming agent CAM. Taking advantage of the solubility of CAM in PVDF/DMF solution (note that sodium bicarbonate is insoluble in DMF solvent), CAM is dissolved in the PVDF/DMF solution to form a polymeric precursor solution. During drying process, the pre-dissolved CAM recrystallizes into micro/nanoparticles that are uniformly dispersed and embedded in the cured PVDF membrane (Fig. 1b). Therefore, when they are immersed in concentrated NaHCO3 aqueous solution, the recrystallized CAM masses react with HCO3 and then are eliminated one by one, resulting in interconnected micro/nano-pores in situ (Fig. 1c). This is the major mechanism of forming porous membrane. Therefore, the content of pore-forming agent CAM has a great effect on the membrane features.
In the experiments, the content of CAM in a constant concentration (6%) of PVDF/DMF solution is tuned from 0 to 1.0 mmol. To determinate the effects of CAM content, the transparency, porosity, wettability and mechanical property of the membranes are investigated, as shown in Fig. S1. With the increasing addition of CAM, it is observed that the transparency of the PVDF membranes decreases gradually from 77% (M1) to 25% (M6), which should be the result of increasing pore density in the membranes. Second, the membrane porosity on both side increases obviously, but the apparent pore size have no significant change. To demonstrate the almost invariant apparent pore size, the Ostwald Ripening phenomenon is taken into account, which occurred during this process for non-uniform pores in a membrane. For the unconfined Ostwald Ripening, tiny crystals are coarsened into a larger one (Fig. 2a). However, in the condition of the sticky polymeric solution system and rapid evaporation rate of solvent, this process is especially confined. The sticky system slows down the coarsening process, and at the same time the solvent is rapidly evaporating. As a result, after drying, the size of CAM crystals is non-uniform but distributed in a certain range (Fig. 2a). Thus, under the same condition of solution viscosity and solvent evaporation rate, increasing the dosage of CAM can only make the number of crystals increased in a certain range of size distribution but the crystal size has no significant change, as well as the apparent pore density and size. In addition, the water contact angle (WCA) and oil contact angle (OCA) in air are shown to be relatively stable, about 80–100° (WCA) and 0° (OCA), respectively. The relative stability of WCA and OCA is attributed to the same surface morphologies and chemical components of the membranes. Specially, to determine the variation of porosity, the filtration rate of pure oil (i.e., 1, 2-dichloroethane) on the membranes from M1 to
M6 is investigated and the result is presented in Fig. 2b. The membrane M1 without adding CAM does not allow the permeation of pure oil, and the gradual increase of oil permeation rate from M2 to M6 reflects the increasing porosity of the membranes with the dosage of CAM. In addition, the CAM content has
significant effect upon the membrane mechanical strength. The mechanical properties of the membranes from M1 to M6 are measured by a typical lifting weight method (i.e., a method of measuring the maximum weight that a strip of membrane can lift in vertical direction) and the result is showed in Fig. 2e. When the dosage of CAM exceeds that of M6, the formed membrane becomes too weak to be lifted up from the liquid surface. Considering the porosity and mechanical strength, the membrane M5 is chosen to do following measurements and separation experiments. For M5, it can be lifted up from the liquid surface by a stainless steel ring without cracking and can be curved or folded arbitrarily after drying, indicating good mechanical strength and excellent flexibility (Fig. 2c and Fig. S3). sections.heading: 3.2. Thickness, surface morphology and elemental analyses of the membrane
sections.text:
To check the thickness and porosity of prepared PVDF membranes, the top/bottom-view and cross-sectional SEM images of the membrane M5 are typically shown in Fig. 3. From the top-view (Fig. 3a) and bottom-view (Fig. 3b) SEM images, one can observe that the surface of the membrane exposed in air is composed of plenty of micro-asperities and pores which is about hundreds of nanometres, while the surface contacted with glass plate is relatively smooth and interspersed with irregular pores and concave pits. These pores and concave pits result from the recrystallized CAM particles which are eliminated in situ in the NaHCO3 solution. It is worth noting that the recrystallized CAM particles are so tiny that they are closely dispersed in the surface and inside of the polymeric membrane, but single tiny crystal cannot completely penetrate through the membrane. Therefore, only cavities rather than through-pores are formed upon the
elimination of the CAM crystals. The interconnected cavities are the spaces that CAM crystals occupied before elimination. As a comparison, the surface morphology of pure PVDFmembraneM1 is observed also and it is found that the top surface of M1 is only composed of rough asperities without perforated pores (Fig. 3c). This contrasting result indicates the significant role of CAM in pore formation as poreforming agent. Further, the cross-sectional SEM image (Fig. 3d) shows that the thickness of the membrane is about 5 mm and interconnected porous structures run through the membrane, for which the liquids can be allowed to permeate through the membrane. Typically, the thickness can be adjusted by changing the concentration of PVDF/ DMF solution, that is, the higher the concentration, the thicker the membrane is. By contrast, phase inverse method is hard to control the membrane thickness under 50 mm [38].
In addition, the element compositions of the membrane M1 and/or M5 are analyzed based on the EDS and XPS data. The content analysis of each element by EDS shows the atomic ratio of element carbon (C), fluorine (F), oxygen (O) in the membrane M5 is 36.19:32.20:3.61 (Fig. S2), which accords with the fact. The slightly higher C atom content and the presence of O atom indicate that there are some CAM residuals in the membrane. Furthermore, the XPS spectra of the PVDF membranes with and without addition of CAM, namely M5 and M1, is shown in Fig. 4a. A relatively strong signal of the peak of oxygen element (O) at the value of 531 eV can be observed in the membrane M5, which results from the residual of CAM that has not been eliminated yet, exactly coinciding with the EDS data. At the same time, a weak signal of oxygen (O) element appears in spectra of membrane M1. This might belong to the impurity, because none of the raw materials of M1 contains oxygen element. sections.heading: 3.3. Surface wetting behaviours and anti-water-fouling property
sections.text:
The surface wettability of the porous PVDF membrane (M5) is measured with respect to the water and oil contact angle in air and/or under oil (1, 2-dichloroethane), showing a selective wetting behaviour. As shown in Fig. 5, the PVDF membrane M5 displayed water contact angle (WCA) of 100° (Fig. 5a) and a nearly zero oil contact angle (OCA) in air (Fig. 5b). Nevertheless, when the PVDF membrane is immersed in oil, the solid-air-oil interface is replaced by a solid-oil-water interface because of the lower surface tension of oil than water. As a result, the under-oil WCA is actual the water-oil contact angle, which is shown to be almost 180° (Fig. 5c).
To check the anti-water-fouling property of the membrane, which is important for oil/water separation, the adhesion of water droplet to the membrane under oil is especially tested in two
ways. The first way is pouring oil into the container, where a water droplet has been deposited the membrane, and observe whether the water droplet can spontaneously break away from the membrane. As shown in Fig. 6a, a water droplet is deposited on the membrane that is fixed in a container for a suspended state, and then the oil (1, 2-dichloroethane) is slowly poured into the container to submerge the membrane. One can observe that the water droplet can spontaneously leave the membrane surface finally, showing extremely low water adhesion under oil. The second way is using a water droplet to contact the membrane that has been submerged by oil. As shown in Fig. 6b, the membrane under oil shows very low adhesive force to water even by pressing action so that the contacted water droplet can be easily separate and fled away without any residues, indicating the great anti-water-fouling property of the membrane (see Movie S1). The selective surface wettability and anti-water-fouling property of the PVDF membrane well satisfy the demand of separating oil/water mixture and water-in-oil emulsion.

sections.heading: 3.4. Separating immiscible oil/water mixtures
sections.text:
For the porosity and selective wettability of the membrane, it is primarily expected to separate two-phase oil/water mixtures. In the separation experiments, the membrane can repeatedly separate the immiscible oil/water mixture with high flux and efficiency under the action of gravity (see Movie S2). In a special way, the oil/ water separation process is carried out on the quoit-hooped PVDF membranes which are fixed with a simple support. As shown in Fig. 7 and Movie S3, 2 mL of oil/water mixture (ratio 1:1, the red is 1, 2-dichloroethane and the blue is water) is poured onto the quoit-hooped PVDF membrane M1 and M5. Obviously, the porous PVDF membrane M5 selectively allows the permeation of oil (red) starting from 15 s and almost completing at 1.5 min but intercepted the water (blue) from beginning to end (Fig. 7b). At the same time, the pure PVDF membrane M1 taken as control group is observed that neither oil nor water can permeate through the membrane during the whole process (5 min) (Fig. 7a). To thoroughly examine the selective permeability, a close-up view is given to the bottoms of the membranes and one can see that a red oil droplet was hanging at the bottom of membrane M5 (Fig. 7b ④), while no any oil or water appears at the bottom of membrane M1 (Fig. 7a ④). Moreover, the anti-water-permeating ability of membrane M5 is measured by raising a water-filled plastic hose until the water penetrated the membrane. As shown in Fig. S4a, the membrane M5 supported with a ceramic filter can bear a water column height of 0.95 m.
Supplementary material related to this article can be found online at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.memsci.2016.08.026.

sections.heading: 3.5. Separating surfactant-stabilized water-in-oil nano-emulsions
sections.text:
Compared with two-phase oil/water mixtures, the surfactantstabilized nanoscale emulsions (SSEs) are more difficult to be separated. Here, two important parameters should be specially

elucidated based on the features of this PVDF membrane: the selective wettability and the efficient pore size of the membrane. Primarily, because of the higher surface tension of water (γlg(water)¼72 dyne/cm) than oil (chloroform as a symbol, γlg(chloroform)¼28.9 dyne/cm) and low surface energy of PVDF, the de-emulsification behaviour can be achieved on the superoleophilic and under-oil superhydrophobic PVDF membrane through preferential wetting behaviour and the pressure difference produced by self-weight. Secondly, for the interconnected porous network structures that run through the membrane, the efficient pore size is further decreases and much smaller than the size of surface pores and emulsions.
To test the emulsion separation capability of the PVDF membrane M5, a series of surfactant-stabilized water-in-oil emulsions with the droplet size at the micro/nanometre scale are prepared in the presence of span 80 (see Table 2). The separation process is conducted on the membrane M5 under self-weight with a liquid column height of 40 cm, which is supported by a ceramic filter (filter radius of 8 mm), as shown in Fig. 8a and Fig. S4b. The results of filtration rate (or flux) and separation efficiency are given in Fig. 8b c. The PVDF membrane M5 can separate the these nano-emulsions with fluxes of 188.99713.93 L m 2 h 1 for water-in-cyclohexane (SSE-1), 95.49711.94 L m 2 h 1 for water-in-isooctane (SSE-2), 79.5873.98 L m 2 h 1 for water-in-n-hexane (SSE-3) and 318.31739.79 L m 2 h 1 for water-in-chloroform (SSE-4) (Fig. 8b). Moreover, the membrane M5 displays high separation efficiencies up to 99.80% for SSE-1, 99.81% for SSE-2, 99.76% for SSE-3% and 99.64% for SSE-4, respectively (Fig. 8c). The comparatively high permeate flux and slightly low efficiency for SSE-4 should be attributed to the higher density of chloroform. Even

though the separation efficiency is very high, the filtrate flux is relatively low, which results from the porous network structure of the membranes and the nanoscale size of the emulsion droplets.
The separation performances are checked in detail by optical microscope and dynamic light scattering (DLS), which are showed in Fig. 9 and Fig. S5. Firstly, from the macroscopic view with naked eye, the initial feed emulsion (water-in-cyclohexane emulsion, SSE-1) is milky (Fig. 9b) but after separation process it became very clear (Fig. 9c). Secondly, from the microscopic view under optical microscope, one can see that the surfactant-stabilized micro/nanometre emulsion droplets are scattered in the oil phase (Fig. 9a), while after separation almost no emulsion droplets are observed in the oil phase (Fig. 9d), showing high separation efficiency. In addition, the droplet size and distribution of various emulsions before and after separation are measured by dynamic light scattering (DLS). Typically, as shown in Fig. 9e f, the size distribution of water-in-cyclohexane emulsion (SSE-1) by volume is ranged from 100 to 300 nm (feed), but after separation it is shifted to 1–10 nm (filtrate), showing the good de-emulsification and high separation efficiency of the PVDF membrane. In detail, the size distribution of various emulsions from SSE-1 to SSE-4 by number before and after separation is shown in Fig. S5. The insets qualitatively exhibited the switching of emulsions from milky to clear. The curve graphs quantitatively display the de-emulsification performance that the size distributions of feed emulsions basically are ranged from 100 nm to 1000 nm, while after separation the emulsion sizes are kept under 10 nm. These results fully prove the feasibility of the porous PVDF membrane obtained by in-situ elimination in oil/water separation.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this work, we fabricate a series of free-standing, thin, porous PVDF membranes at low cost by a new and simple process of tape-
casting, drying and immersing. Substantially, the citric acid monohydrate (CAM) as pore-forming agent plays a crucial role in the formation of interconnected porous structures. Because the immersing process eliminated the recrystallized CAM particles in membrane for pore forming, this new method is referred to as insitu elimination. The effects of the CAM dosage on surface porosity and mechanical property are investigated, that the increasing porosity is at the cost of mechanical strength. Therefore, an optimal membrane is chosen, that is, membrane M5. The apparent pore size of the membrane ranges from tens to hundreds nanometres and the thickness can be controlled under 5 mm. Moreover, the PVDF membrane displays superoleophilic and under-oil superhydrophobic properties. Because of the porosity and selective wettability, it can not only separate two-phase oil/water mixtures with high flux and efficiency, but also separate surfactant-stabilized water-in-oil nano-emulsions with filtration rate of 318.31739.79 L m 2 h 1 and high efficiency of 99.64%. This method not only provides a new, simple and low-cost way to manufacture porous PVDF membrane in the field of membrane science, but also provides an energy-efficient strategy to separate oil/water mixtures in the field of watery waste-oil treatment.

metadata.abstractText: The influences and treatments of oil/water mixtures have been plaguing people for many years. To deal with it, the fabrication of separation membranes becomes a significant technology in the application to oily wastewater treatment. Except for the well-known phase inversion method which is promising for polymeric separation membrane fabrication, another imaginable method referred to as in-situ elimination here still suffers from major difficulty in the uniform dispersion of dissoluble micro/nano-particles in polymeric matrix. Aiming at in-situ elimination method, a series of free-standing thin PVDF membranes with interconnected porous structures are fabricated based on low-cost starting materials through a simple process of tape-casting, drying and immersing, in the presence of pore-forming agent of citric acid monohydrate (CAM). Substantially, the pore formation mechanism is studied, which is resulted from the recrystallization of pore-forming agent (CAM) and subsequent in-situ elimination in NaHCO3 solution. The fabricated free-standing porous PVDF membrane with thickness of 5 mm and surface pore size of o500 nm showed great flexibility and superoleophilic, under-oil superhydrophobic, anti-water-fouling properties. For the porosity and selective wettability, their applications in oil/water separation are studied also and the results show that the PVDF membrane can separate not only immiscible oil/water mixtures quickly but also various surfactant-stabilized water-in-oil nanoscale emulsions, with filtration flux up to 318 L m 2 h 1 and separation efficiency of 99.81% under the action of self-gravity. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time the polymeric separation membranes have been positively fabricated by in-situ elimination, which provides a new avenue for porous polymeric membrane fabrication in membrane science field and shows the application in oil/water or emulsion separation. This work provides a new porous membrane-forming method and an energy-efficient strategy for separating immiscible oil/water mixtures and surfactant-stabilized water-in-oil nanoemulsions. & 2016 Elsevier B.V.
